title: 112_hr5947
content: The Act titled "Justice Exists for All of Us Act of 2012" addresses state "Stand Your Ground" laws and neighborhood watch registration. The "Justice Exists for All of Us Act of 2012" prohibits states from having "stand your ground" laws allowing deadly force without a duty to retreat, except for domestic violence victims. States must also have laws against unlawful establishment of neighborhood watch programs. The "Justice Exists for All of Us Act of 2012" mandates that states must register Neighborhood Watch programs with local law enforcement and the Department of Justice. States have a 3-year deadline to implement this requirement, with possible extensions granted by the Attorney General. Failure to comply may result in consequences for the state. The "Justice Exists for All of Us Act of 2012" requires states to register Neighborhood Watch programs with law enforcement and the Department of Justice within a 3-year deadline. Failure to comply may lead to the withholding of 20 percent of allocated funds under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. The Attorney General will assess state implementation, considering constitutional limitations. The "Justice Exists for All of Us Act of 2012" requires states to register Neighborhood Watch programs with law enforcement and the Department of Justice within a 3-year deadline. The Attorney General and the State must make good faith efforts to implement the section and resolve any conflicts with the State's constitution as determined by the State's highest court. The Act requires states to register Neighborhood Watch programs with law enforcement and the Department of Justice within a 3-year deadline. If a state faces constitutional limitations, the Attorney General may approve alternative procedures. Non-compliance may result in funding reduction. Amounts not allocated may be reallocated under specific conditions. Funds withheld from a state for not implementing a section of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 may be reallocated to states in compliance or used for implementing the section. The term "State" is defined in the Act.
